normalised: ## Finding My Balance: An Ayurvedic Journey in Kerala

unnormalised: The frantic pace of Mumbai life had finally caught up with me. Sleepless nights fuelled by chai and endless deadlines had left me feeling depleted. My skin was dull, my energy levels were non-existent, and even my favorite vada pav couldn't lift my spirits. I knew I needed a change, a complete reset. That’s when I started seriously considering Ayurveda.
normalised: The frantic pace of Mumbai life had finally caught up with me. Sleepless nights fuelled by chai and endless deadlines had left me feeling depleted. My skin was dull, my energy levels were non-existent, and even my favorite vada pav couldn't lift my spirits. I knew I needed a change, a complete reset. That’s when I started seriously considering Ayurveda.

unnormalised: I’d heard whispers about the power of Ayurveda – the ancient Indian system of medicine – from my grandmother, Aaji. She swore by her daily tulsi tea and insisted on using haldi (turmeric) for everything, from cuts to coughs. But I'd always dismissed it as old wives' tales. Now, desperate for relief, I decided to delve deeper.

Now, desperate for relief, I decided to delve deeper.

unnormalised: My research led me to Kerala, the land of Ayurveda. After hours of online browsing and phone calls (at truly ungodly hours, like 03:00 hrs IST!), I booked a two-week stay at an Ayurvedic retreat near Kovalam. The initial consultation with the Vaidya (Ayurvedic doctor) was fascinating. He took my pulse, examined my tongue, and asked me a million questions. He diagnosed a Vata imbalance and prescribed a personalized treatment plan involving abhyanga (oil massage), shirodhara (oil pouring on the forehead), and a specific diet.

He diagnosed a Vata imbalance and prescribed a personalized treatment plan involving abhyanga (oil massage), shirodhara (oil pouring on the forehead), and a specific diet.

unnormalised: The first few days were challenging. Waking up at 06:00 hrs for yoga was a shock to my system! And the diet – primarily kitchari (a mung bean and rice dish) – took some getting used to. There were no Starbucks lattes or pizzas in sight. But slowly, something shifted. The daily massages melted away the tension that had been building up for years. The shirodhara sessions were incredibly calming, and I started sleeping better than I had in months.

unnormalised: The Vaidya also recommended some lifestyle changes, like incorporating more spices like ginger and cardamom into my diet, and practicing mindfulness meditation for 15 minutes every morning. He even gave me a specific herbal concoction to take – a Kadha – which he claimed would help balance my doshas.

unnormalised: By the end of the two weeks, on 26/01/2023, I felt like a new person. My skin was glowing, my energy was restored, and my mind was clear. I learned the importance of listening to my body and making conscious choices that support my well-being. The experience wasn't just a vacation; it was a journey of self-discovery. It's been a few months since my trip, and I'm still incorporating the principles of Ayurveda into my daily life. Aaji, it turns out, was right all along! My next appointment is on 10/11/2024, and I'm already looking forward to it.
